title: Nanoroughness induced anti-reflection and haze effects in opaque systems
abstract:
How to make a material anti-reflective without changing its high refraction
index? Achieving anti-reflection in high-refractive-index materials poses
challenges due to their high reflectivity (Fresnel equations). Based on theory
with new boundary conditions, we propose modifying surface properties on a
nanoscale to tackle this. Our study on weakly rough opaque surfaces reveals
significant changes in specular and diffuse scattering, predicting
anti-reflection where roughness matches light penetration depth for the first
time. Experimental validation on nano-roughened Si films (at wavelengths
300-400 nm) supports our findings. We also analyze angular and polarization
dependences of nanoroughness-induced haze, showing predominant p-polarization
and minimal haze at nanoscale, yet impactful specular reflection reduction.
subjects: Condensed Matter/Disordered Systems and Neural Networks
